company.name: Ascension Data & Analytics, LLC
company.business_description: Ascension Data & Analytics, LLC is an analytics company that provides data, analytics, and system-based technology services and products to other companies in its corporate family in connection with mortgages. Services include systems development such as document management systems and automation of data-driven decision-making, creating valuation models and comparative market analyses, and various due diligence reviews including title searches and foreclosure docket analyses.

case_info.legal_authority: Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title I of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley (GLB) Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.; violations enforced through the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6805(a)(7)

complaint.factual_background: Ascension Data & Analytics, LLC, an analytics company providing mortgage-related services, contracted with a third-party vendor (OpticsML) to conduct OCR scanning on mortgage documents containing sensitive personal information of approximately 60,593 consumers. Despite its own written policy requiring security vetting of service providers, Ascension did nothing to assess OpticsML's security measures before handing over the sensitive data. OpticsML misconfigured its cloud-based storage, leaving the personal information — including names, Social Security numbers, credit account numbers, and financial data — publicly accessible on the internet without a password for approximately one year (January 2018 to January 2019). During that period, approximately 52 unauthorized IP addresses accessed the exposed data, many from outside the United States including Russia and China. Ascension also failed to include adequate contractual safeguard requirements in its service provider agreements, in violation of the FTC's Gramm-Leach-Bliley Safeguards Rule.

representations_made.description: Ascension maintained a 'Third Party Vendor Risk Management' policy describing due diligence steps — including obtaining security policies, procedures, and questionnaires from service providers — but failed to follow those steps in practice
representations_made.quoted_text: 15. Since at least July 2016, Respondent maintained a “Third Party Vendor Risk Management” policy describing the due diligence Respondent required for service providers. The policy recommends numerous steps Respondent’s Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) and business managers were to take to evaluate service providers, such as having service providers provide their policies and procedures and fill out an information security questionnaire.

representations_made.description: Ascension's service provider contracts included only a vague GLB Act non-disclosure clause, without specifying that service providers were responsible for implementing appropriate safeguards under the Safeguards Rule
representations_made.quoted_text: 17. Since at least September 2016, Respondent has also failed to require service providers by contract to implement appropriate safeguards for personal information that Respondent provided to those service providers. Instead, Respondent’s service provider contracts have only included an agreement that “any nonpublic personal information . . . shall be protected from disclosure with all the provisions of the Gramm-Leach-Bailey [sic] Act,” and not disclosed by either party without prior written consent. But these clauses did not make clear that the service providers, including OpticsML, were responsible for protecting the information in accordance with the GLB’s Safeguards Rule, or that they were even subject to the rule. Respondent’s service provider contracts failed to specify safeguards that service providers must implement, or otherwise require them to take reasonable steps to secure personal information.

representations_made.description: Ascension's own policy required it to 'contractually require its third party vendors to implement appropriate measures' with respect to customer information, but its contracts did not satisfy this requirement
representations_made.quoted_text: 18. Indeed, Respondent’s service provider contracts do not satisfy its Third Party Vendor Risk Management policy, which requires Respondent to “contractually require its third party vendors to implement appropriate measures” with respect to customer information.

representations_made.description: Ascension's 'Third Party Vendor Risk Management' policy required its CISO to complete a quantitative assessment of risk for each service provider, but Ascension did not conduct adequate risk assessments prior to September 2017 and did not assess risks related to service providers including OpticsML
representations_made.quoted_text: 20. Prior to September 2017, Respondent did not conduct adequate risk assessment. During this time, Respondent also did not assess risks related to its service providers, even though its “Third Party Vendor Risk Management” policy required its CISO to “complete a quantitative assessment of risk” for each service provider.

counts.title: Violation of the GLB Safeguards Rule
counts.representation: Ascension failed to oversee service providers by taking reasonable steps to select and retain service providers capable of maintaining appropriate safeguards for customer information, and failed to require service providers by contract to implement such safeguards. Ascension also failed to identify reasonably foreseeable internal and external risks to the security, confidentiality, and integrity of customer information and failed to assess the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to control those risks.
counts.fact: The Safeguards Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314) requires financial institutions to develop, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program including overseeing service providers and conducting risk assessments. Ascension, as a financial institution handling nonpublic personal information, was subject to these requirements but failed to comply with them.
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the conduct set forth in Paragraphs 23-24 is a violation of the Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314.

definitions.Covered Business: Respondent or any business that Respondent controls.
definitions.Covered Incident: any instance in which any United States federal, state, or local law or regulation requires a Covered Business to notify any U.S. federal, state, or local government entity that information from or about an individual consumer was, or is reasonably believed to have been, accessed or acquired without authorization.
definitions.Covered Information: (1) Personally Identifiable Financial Information; and (2) any list, description, or other grouping of consumers (and publicly available information pertaining to them) that is derived using any Personally Identifiable Financial Information that is not publicly available.
definitions.Personally Identifiable Financial Inform: any information: 1. A consumer provides to obtain a financial product or service; 2. About a consumer resulting from any transaction involving a financial product or service; or 3. A Covered Business otherwise obtains about a consumer in connection with providing a financial product or service to that consumer.
definitions.Respondent: Ascension Data & Analytics, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company, and its successors and assigns.
definitions.Vendor: any person or entity that receives, maintains, processes, or otherwise is permitted access to Covered Information from, by, or at the direction of a Covered Business through its provision of services directly to a Covered Business.

provisions.title: GLB Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Respondent and all persons acting in concert with it must not violate any provision of the Standards for Safeguarding Consumer Information Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314).

requirements.description: Must not violate any provision of the Standards for Safeguarding Consumer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that Respondent, and Respondent’s officers, agents, employees and attorneys, and all other persons in active concert or participation with any of them, who receive actual notice of this Order, whether acting directly or indirectly, in connection with any product or service, must not violate any provision of the Standards for Safeguarding Consumer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314, a copy of which is attached hereto as Exhibit A.

provisions.title: Mandated Data Security Program
provisions.summary: Each Covered Business must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive data security program protecting Covered Information, meeting numerous specific minimum requirements.

requirements.description: Must not transfer, sell, share, collect, maintain, or store Covered Information unless a comprehensive Data Security Program is established, implemented, and maintained
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that each Covered Business must not transfer, sell, share, collect, maintain, or store Covered Information unless it establishes and implements, and thereafter maintains, a comprehensive data security program (“Data Security Program”) that protects the security of such Covered Information. To satisfy this requirement, each Covered Business must, at a minimum:

requirements.description: Document in writing the content, implementation, and maintenance of the Data Security Program
requirements.quoted_text: A. Document in writing the content, implementation, and maintenance of the Data Security Program;

requirements.description: Provide the written program and any evaluations or updates to the board of directors or governing body (or senior officer) at least once every twelve months and promptly after a Covered Incident
requirements.quoted_text: B. Provide the written program and any evaluations thereof or updates thereto to its board of directors or governing body or, if no such board or equivalent governing body exists, to a senior officer responsible for its Data Security Program at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly after a Covered Incident;
requirements.deadline: annually and promptly after Covered Incident

requirements.description: Designate a qualified employee or employees to coordinate and be responsible for the Data Security Program
requirements.quoted_text: C. Designate a qualified employee or employees to coordinate and be responsible for the Data Security Program;

requirements.description: Assess and document internal and external risks to the security of Covered Information at least once every twelve months and promptly after a Covered Incident, evaluating employee training, information systems, and incident response areas
requirements.quoted_text: D. Assess and document, at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly following a Covered Incident, internal and external risks to the security of Covered Information that could result in the unauthorized disclosure, misuse, loss, theft, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information. Each such assessment must evaluate risks in each area of relevant operation, including: (1) employee training and management; (2) information systems, such as network and software design, information processing, storage, transmission, and disposal; and (3) prevention, detection, and response to attacks, intrusions, or other systems failures;
requirements.deadline: annually and promptly after Covered Incident

requirements.description: Design, implement, maintain, and document safeguards controlling internal and external risks; safeguards must be based on volume and sensitivity of Covered Information and likelihood of risk realization
requirements.quoted_text: E. Design, implement, maintain, and document safeguards that control the internal and external risks identified in response to sub-Provision II.D. Each safeguard must be based on the volume and sensitivity of the Covered Information at risk, and the likelihood that the risk could be realized and result in the unauthorized disclosure, misuse, loss, theft, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information. Each Covered Business’s safeguards must also include:

requirements.description: Require each Vendor, before being given access to Covered Information, to provide documentation of its information security policies and practices and describe in writing how and where Covered Information will be maintained and what safeguards are in place
requirements.quoted_text: 1. Require each Vendor to: 3 a. Before the Covered Business provides access to Covered Information: i. Provide documentation of its information security policies and practices related to protecting any Covered Information that may be obtained from the Covered Business; ii. Describe in writing how and where the Covered Information will be maintained and what safeguards are in place or will be implemented to protect it;

requirements.description: Require each Vendor to update in writing the required information when there is a material change or at least once every twelve months
requirements.quoted_text: b. Update in writing the information required by sub-Provision II.E.1.a when there is a material change or at least once every twelve (12) months; and

requirements.description: Require each Vendor to implement measures to assess cybersecurity risk to Covered Information stored on Vendor networks and provide documentation of scope and results, including vulnerability scanning and penetration testing, at least once every twelve months and promptly after a Covered Incident
requirements.quoted_text: c. Implement measures to assess the cybersecurity risk to Covered Information obtained from the Covered Business that is stored on the Vendor’s networks, if any, and if any is stored, provide documentation to the Covered Business of the scope of the measures and their results, including, at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly after a Covered Incident: (i) vulnerability scanning; and (ii) penetration testing;
requirements.deadline: annually and promptly after Covered Incident

requirements.description: Maintain all documentation provided by each Vendor for five years from when it was provided
requirements.quoted_text: 2. Maintain all documentation provided by each Vendor pursuant to sub-Provision II.E.1 for a period of five (5) years from when it was provided; and

requirements.description: At least once every twelve months and promptly following a Covered Incident involving a Vendor, conduct written assessments of each Vendor to determine continued adequacy of safeguards
requirements.quoted_text: 3. At least once every twelve (12) months, and promptly following a Covered Incident involving a Vendor, conduct written assessments of each Vendor to determine the continued adequacy of their safeguards to control the internal and external risks to the security of Covered Information. The level of the assessment for each Vendor should be commensurate with the risk it poses to the security of Covered Information.
requirements.deadline: annually and promptly after Covered Incident

requirements.description: Vendor documentation requirements (sub-Provisions II.E.1-3) are not required for Vendors that receive access only to names and/or property addresses and no other Covered Information
requirements.quoted_text: 4. Provided, however, that sub-Provisions II.E.1-3 are not required of any Covered Business for a Vendor that receives, maintains, processes, or otherwise is permitted access to only names and/or property addresses, and to no other Covered Information, from, by, or at the direction of the Covered Business.

requirements.description: Assess at least once every twelve months and promptly after a Covered Incident the sufficiency of safeguards, and modify the Data Security Program based on results
requirements.quoted_text: F. Assess, at least once every twelve (12) months and promptly following a Covered Incident, the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to address the risks to the security of Covered Information, and modify the Data Security Program based on the results;
requirements.deadline: annually and promptly after Covered Incident

requirements.description: Test and monitor effectiveness of safeguards at least once every twelve months and promptly after a Covered Incident, and modify the Data Security Program based on results
requirements.quoted_text: G. Test and monitor the effectiveness of the safeguards at least once every twelve (12) months, and promptly following a Covered Incident, and modify the Data Security Program based on the results;
requirements.deadline: annually and promptly after Covered Incident

requirements.description: Select and retain Vendors capable of safeguarding Covered Information, and contractually require Vendors to implement and maintain safeguards for Covered Information
requirements.quoted_text: H. Select and retain Vendors capable of safeguarding Covered Information they access through or receive from Covered Businesses, and contractually require Vendors to implement and maintain safeguards for Covered Information; and

requirements.description: Evaluate and adjust the Data Security Program in light of changes to operations, business arrangements, a Covered Incident, or other circumstances that may affect its effectiveness; at minimum, evaluate at least once every twelve months and modify based on results
requirements.quoted_text: I. Evaluate and adjust the Data Security Program in light of any changes to its operations or business arrangements, a Covered Incident, or any other circumstances that each Covered Business knows or has reason to know may have an impact on the effectiveness of the Data Security Program. At a minimum, each Covered Business must evaluate the Data Security Program at least once every twelve (12) months and modify the Data Security Program based on the results.

provisions.title: Data Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of each Covered Business's Data Security Program from a qualified, independent assessor, with specific reporting and submission requirements.

requirements.description: Obtain initial and biennial assessments from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional who uses generally accepted procedures, conducts an independent review, and retains all documents for five years, providing them to the Commission within ten days of a written request
requirements.quoted_text: A. The Assessments must be obtained from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional (“Assessor”), who: (1) uses procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession; (2) conducts an independent review of the Data Security Program; and (3) retains all documents relevant to each Assessment for five (5) years after completion of such Assessment and will provide such documents to the Commission within ten (10) days of receipt of a written request from a representative of the Commission. No documents may be withheld on the basis of a claim of confidentiality, proprietary or trade secrets, work product protection, attorney client privilege, statutory exemption, or any similar claim.
requirements.deadline: initial: 180 days; biennial thereafter for 10 years

requirements.description: For each Assessment, provide the Associate Director for Enforcement at the FTC with the name and affiliation of the selected Assessor, subject to the Associate Director's approval
requirements.quoted_text: B. For each Assessment, Respondent must provide the Associate Director for Enforcement for the Bureau of Consumer Protection at the Federal Trade Commission with the name and affiliation of the person selected to conduct the Assessment, which the Associate Director shall have the authority to approve in his or her sole discretion.

requirements.description: Reporting period must cover the first 180 days after the Order issuance date for the initial Assessment, and each 2-year period thereafter for ten years for biennial Assessments
requirements.quoted_text: C. The reporting period for the Assessments must cover: (1) the first 180 days after the issuance date of the Order for the initial Assessment; and (2) each 2-year period thereafter for ten (10) years after issuance of the Order for the biennial Assessments.
requirements.deadline: 180 days for initial; 2-year periods for 10 years for biennial

requirements.description: Each Assessment must determine whether the Data Security Program has been implemented and maintained, assess its effectiveness, identify gaps or weaknesses, identify specific supporting evidence, and be signed by the Assessor without relying solely on management assertions
requirements.quoted_text: D. Each Assessment must: (1) determine whether each Covered Business has implemented and maintained the Data Security Program required by Provision II of this Order, titled Mandated Data Security Program; (2) assess the effectiveness of each Covered Business’s implementation and maintenance of sub-Provisions II.A-I; (3) identify any gaps or weaknesses in the Data Security Program; and (4) identify specific evidence (including, but not limited to documents reviewed, sampling and testing performed, and interviews conducted) examined to make such determinations, assessments, and identifications, and explain why the evidence that the Assessor examined is sufficient to justify the Assessor’s findings. No finding of any Assessment shall rely solely on assertions or attestations by a Covered Business’s management. The Assessment must be signed by the Assessor and must state that the Assessor conducted an independent review of the Data Security Program, and did not rely solely on assertions or attestations by a Covered Business’s management.

requirements.description: Each Assessment must be completed within sixty days after the end of the reporting period; initial Assessment must be submitted to the Commission within ten days after completion; subsequent biennial Assessments must be retained until the order terminates and provided to the Associate Director within ten days of request
requirements.quoted_text: E. Each Assessment must be completed within sixty (60) days after the end of the reporting period to which the Assessment applies. Unless otherwise directed by a Commission representative in writing, Respondent must submit its initial Assessment to the Commission within ten (10) days after the Assessment has been completed via email to DEbrief@ftc.gov or by overnight courier (not the U.S. Postal Service) to Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20580. The subject line must begin, “In re Ascension Data & Analytics, LLC, FTC File No. 1923126.” All subsequent biennial Assessments must be retained by Respondent until the order is terminated and provided to the Associate Director for Enforcement within ten (10) days of request.
requirements.deadline: 60 days after reporting period end; 10 days to submit initial

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondent must fully cooperate with the Assessor by disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation, and providing all relevant information and materials in its possession.

requirements.description: Disclose all material facts to the Assessor and not misrepresent any fact material to the Assessor's determinations regarding the Data Security Program
requirements.quoted_text: A. Disclose all material facts to the Assessor, and not misrepresent in any manner, expressly or by implication, any fact material to the Assessor’s: (1) determination of whether the Covered Business has implemented and maintained the Data Security Program required by Provision II of this Order, titled Mandated Data Security Program; (2) assessment of the effectiveness of the implementation and maintenance of sub-Provisions II.A-I; or (3) identification of any gaps or weaknesses in the Data Security Program; and

requirements.description: Provide or make available to the Assessor all relevant information and material in Respondent's possession, custody, or control for which there is no reasonable claim of privilege
requirements.quoted_text: B. Provide or otherwise make available to the Assessor all information and material in their possession, custody, or control that is relevant to the Assessment for which there is no reasonable claim of privilege.

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide the Commission with annual certifications from a senior corporate manager or officer confirming compliance with the Order, awareness of no uncorrected material noncompliance, and a description of any Covered Incidents.

requirements.description: One year after the Order issuance date, and each year thereafter, provide the Commission with a certification from a senior corporate manager or senior officer of each Covered Business confirming: (1) establishment and maintenance of Order requirements; (2) no material noncompliance not corrected or disclosed; and (3) a brief description of any Covered Incident
requirements.quoted_text: A. One year after the issuance date of this Order, and each year thereafter, provide the Commission with a certification from a senior corporate manager, or, if no such senior corporate manager exists, a senior officer of each Covered Business responsible for each Covered Business’s Data Security Program that: (1) each Covered Business has established, implemented, and maintained the requirements of this Order; (2) each Covered Business is not aware of any material noncompliance that has not been (a) corrected or (b) disclosed to the Commission; and (3) includes a brief description of any Covered Incident. The certification must be based on the personal knowledge of the senior corporate manager, senior officer, or subject matter experts upon whom the senior corporate manager or senior officer reasonably relies in making the certification.

requirements.description: Submit all annual certifications to the Commission via email to DEbrief@ftc.gov or by overnight courier to the FTC's Associate Director for Enforcement, with a specified subject line
requirements.quoted_text: B. Unless otherwise directed by a Commission representative in writing, submit all annual certifications to the Commission pursuant to this Order via email to DEbrief@ftc.gov or by overnight courier (not the U.S. Postal Service) to Associate Director for Enforcement, 6 Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20580. The subject line must begin, “In re Ascension Data & Analytics, LLC, FTC File No. 1923126.”

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a report to the Commission within ten days of first notifying any government entity of a Covered Incident, including specified details about the incident and remediation steps.

requirements.description: Within a reasonable time after discovering a Covered Incident, but no later than ten days after first notifying any U.S. federal, state, or local government entity, submit a report to the Commission
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Respondent, for any Covered Business, within a reasonable time after the date of discovery of a Covered Incident, but in any event no later than ten (10) days after the date the Covered Business first notifies any U.S. federal, state, or local government entity of the Covered Incident, must submit a report to the Commission. The report must include, to the extent possible:

requirements.description: The report must include: (A) date or date range of the incident; (B) description of facts and causes; (C) types of information triggering notification; (D) number of affected consumers; (E) remediation actions taken; and (F) a representative copy of each materially different notice sent to consumers or government entities
requirements.quoted_text: A. The date, estimated date, or estimated date range when the Covered Incident occurred; B. A description of the facts relating to the Covered Incident, including the causes of the Covered Incident, if known; C. A description of each type of information that triggered the notification obligation to the U.S. federal, state, or local government entity; D. The number of consumers whose information triggered the notification obligation to the U.S. federal, state, or local government entity; E. The acts that the Covered Business has taken to date to remediate the Covered Incident and protect Covered Information from further exposure or access, and protect affected individuals from identity theft or other harm that may result from the Covered Incident; and F. A representative copy of each materially different notice required by U.S. federal, state, or local law or regulation and sent by the Covered Business or any of its clients to consumers or to any U.S. federal, state, or local government entity.

requirements.description: Submit all Covered Incident reports via email to DEbrief@ftc.gov or by overnight courier to the FTC's Associate Director for Enforcement, with the specified subject line
requirements.quoted_text: Unless otherwise directed by a Commission representative in writing, all Covered Incident reports to the Commission pursuant to this Order must be emailed to DEbrief@ftc.gov or sent by overnight courier (not the U.S. Postal Service) to Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20580. The subject line must begin, “In re Ascension Data & Analytics, LLC, FTC File No. 1923126.”

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must acknowledge receipt of the Order, deliver copies to relevant personnel and entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt.

requirements.description: Within ten days after the effective date of the Order, submit to the Commission an acknowledgment of receipt of the Order sworn under penalty of perjury
requirements.quoted_text: A. Respondent, within ten (10) days after the effective date of this Order, must submit to the Commission an acknowledgment of receipt of this Order sworn under penalty of perjury.

requirements.description: For twenty years after the Order issuance date, deliver a copy of the Order to all principals, officers, directors, LLC managers and members, employees with managerial responsibilities related to the Order, agents and representatives participating in related conduct, and any successor business entities; delivery must occur within ten days of the effective date for current personnel and before assumption of responsibilities for all others
requirements.quoted_text: B. For twenty (20) years after the issuance date of this Order, Respondent must deliver a copy of this Order to: (1) all principals, officers, directors, and LLC managers and members; (2) all employees having managerial responsibilities for conduct related to the subject matter of the Order and all agents and representatives who participate in conduct related to the subject matter of the Order; and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure as set forth in the Provision VIII of this Order titled Compliance Report and Notices. Delivery must occur within ten (10) days after the effective date of this Order for current personnel. For all others, delivery must occur before they assume their responsibilities.
requirements.deadline: 10 days for current personnel; before assuming responsibilities for others

requirements.description: From each individual or entity that received a copy of the Order, obtain within thirty days a signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt
requirements.quoted_text: C. From each individual or entity to which Respondent delivered a copy of this Order, Respondent must obtain, within thirty (30) days, a signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt of this Order.

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an initial compliance report one year after the Order, and timely notices of changes in contact information, organizational structure, or bankruptcy proceedings.

requirements.description: One year after the Order issuance date, submit a sworn compliance report identifying contact information, all businesses and their activities, describing compliance with each Order provision, and providing copies of acknowledgments obtained
requirements.quoted_text: A. One year after the issuance date of this Order, Respondent must submit a compliance report, sworn under penalty of perjury, in which Respondent must: (a) identify the primary physical, postal, and email address, and telephone number, as designated points of contact, which representatives of the Commission may use to communicate with Respondent; (b) identify all of Respondent’s businesses by all of their names, telephone numbers, and physical, postal, email, and Internet addresses; (c) describe the activities of each business, including the goods and services offered, and the means of advertising, marketing, and sales; (d) describe in detail whether and how Respondent is in compliance with each Provision of this Order, including a discussion of all of the changes Respondent made to comply with the Order; and (e) provide a copy of each Acknowledgment of the Order obtained pursuant to this Order, unless previously submitted to the Commission.

requirements.description: Within fourteen days of any change in designated points of contact or in Respondent's structure (including mergers, sales, or dissolutions of related entities), submit a sworn compliance notice
requirements.quoted_text: B. Respondent must submit a compliance notice, sworn under penalty of perjury, within fourteen (14) days of any change in the following: (a) any designated point of contact; or (b) the structure of Respondent or any entity that Respondent has any ownership interest in or controls directly or indirectly that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Order, including: creation, merger, sale, or dissolution of the entity or any subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this Order.

requirements.description: Submit notice of the filing of any bankruptcy petition, insolvency proceeding, or similar proceeding within fourteen days of its filing
requirements.quoted_text: C. Respondent must submit notice of the filing of any bankruptcy petition, insolvency proceeding, or similar proceeding by or against Respondent within fourteen (14) days of its filing.

requirements.description: All submissions required to be sworn under penalty of perjury must be true and accurate and comply with 28 U.S.C. § 1746, concluding with the required declaration language including date, full name, title, and signature
requirements.quoted_text: D. Any submission to the Commission required by this Order to be sworn under penalty of perjury must be true and accurate and comply with 28 U.S.C. § 1746, such as by 8 concluding: “I declare under penalty of perjury under the laws of the United States of America that the foregoing is true and correct. Executed on: _____” and supplying the date, signatory’s full name, title (if applicable), and signature.

requirements.description: Unless otherwise directed, all submissions must be emailed to DEbrief@ftc.gov or sent by overnight courier to the FTC's Associate Director for Enforcement, with the specified subject line
requirements.quoted_text: E. Unless otherwise directed by a Commission representative in writing, all submissions to the Commission pursuant to this Order must be emailed to DEbrief@ftc.gov or sent by overnight courier (not the U.S. Postal Service) to: Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20580. The subject line must begin, “In re Ascension Data & Analytics, LLC, FTC File No. 1923126.”

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for twenty years after the Order issuance date and retain each record for five years, unless otherwise specified.

requirements.description: Create and retain accounting records showing revenues from all goods or services sold
requirements.quoted_text: A. Accounting records showing the revenues from all goods or services sold;

requirements.description: Create and retain personnel records showing each service provider's name, addresses, telephone numbers, job title, dates of service, and reason for termination
requirements.quoted_text: B. Personnel records showing, for each person providing services in relation to any aspect of the Order, whether as an employee or otherwise, that person’s name; addresses; telephone numbers; job title or position; dates of service; and (if applicable) the reason for termination;

requirements.description: Retain copies or records of all consumer complaints and refund requests, whether received directly or through a third party, and any responses
requirements.quoted_text: C. Copies or records of all consumer complaints and refund requests, whether received directly or indirectly, such as through a third party, and any response;

requirements.description: For five years after the date of preparation of each Assessment, retain all materials and evidence the Assessor considered or reviewed, including plans, reports, audits, policies, training materials, and other compliance-related materials
requirements.quoted_text: D. For five (5) years after the date of preparation of each Assessment required by this Order, all materials and evidence that the Assessor considered, reviewed, relied upon or examined to prepare the Assessment, whether prepared by or on behalf of a Covered Business, including all plans, reports, studies, reviews, audits, audit trails, policies, training materials, and assessments, and any other materials concerning Covered Businesses’ compliance with related Provisions of this Order, for the compliance period covered by such Assessment;

requirements.description: For five years from the date received, retain copies of all subpoenas and other communications with law enforcement relating to a Covered Business's compliance with the Order
requirements.quoted_text: E. For five (5) years from the date received, copies of all subpoenas and other communications with law enforcement, if such communications relate to a Covered Business’s compliance with this Order;

requirements.description: For five years from the date created or received, retain all records addressing compliance or noncompliance with the Order
requirements.quoted_text: F. For five (5) years from the date created or received, all records, whether prepared by or on behalf of a Covered Business, that address compliance by a Covered Business with this Order or lack thereof; and

requirements.description: Retain all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance with each Order provision, including all submissions to the Commission
requirements.quoted_text: G. All records necessary to demonstrate full compliance with each Provision of this Order, including all submissions to the Commission.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting reports and records, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.

requirements.description: Within ten days of receipt of a written request from a Commission representative, submit additional compliance reports or other requested information sworn under penalty of perjury, and produce records for inspection and copying
requirements.quoted_text: A. Within ten (10) days of receipt of a written request from a representative of the Commission, Respondent must submit additional compliance reports or other requested information, which must be sworn under penalty of perjury, and produce records for inspection and copying.

requirements.description: Permit Commission representatives to communicate directly with Respondent and to interview anyone affiliated with Respondent who has agreed to such an interview; interviewee may have counsel present
requirements.quoted_text: B. For matters concerning this Order, representatives of the Commission are authorized to communicate directly with Respondent. Respondent must permit representatives of the Commission to interview anyone affiliated with Respondent who has agreed to such an interview. The interviewee may have counsel present.

requirements.description: The Commission may use all other lawful means, including posing as consumers or suppliers, without prior notice; nothing in the Order limits the Commission's use of compulsory process under FTC Act Sections 9 and 20
requirements.quoted_text: C. The Commission may use all other lawful means, including posing through its representatives as consumers, suppliers, or other individuals or entities, to Respondent or any individual or entity affiliated with Respondent, without the necessity of identification or prior notice. Nothing in this Order limits the Commission’s lawful use of compulsory process, pursuant to Sections 9 and 20 of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 49, 57b-1.

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates on December 22, 2041, or twenty years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later.

requirements.description: Order is final and effective upon publication on the Commission's website as a final order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Order is final and effective upon the date of its publication on the Commission’s website (ftc.gov) as a final order. This Order will terminate on

requirements.description: Order terminates on December 22, 2041, or twenty years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later; exceptions apply for provisions terminating earlier, non-defendant respondents, and orders already terminated
requirements.quoted_text: publication on the Commission’s website (ftc.gov) as a final order. This Order will terminate on December 22, 2041, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying settlement) in federal court alleging any violation of this Order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. Any Provision in this Order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. This Order’s application to any Respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. This Order if such complaint is filed after the Order has terminated pursuant to this Provision.
requirements.deadline: December 22, 2041 or 20 years from most recent complaint

requirements.description: If a complaint filed to extend the Order is dismissed or Respondent is found not to have violated the Order, and that result is not appealed or is upheld on appeal, the Order terminates as though the complaint had never been filed, except it will not terminate during the pendency of any appeal
requirements.quoted_text: Provided, further, that if such complaint is dismissed or a federal court rules that the Respondent did not violate any Provision of the Order, and the dismissal or ruling is either not appealed or upheld on appeal, then the Order will terminate according to this Provision as though the complaint had never been filed, except that the Order will not terminate between the date such complaint is filed and the later of the deadline for appealing such dismissal or ruling and the date such dismissal or ruling is upheld on appeal.

duration.termination_text: This Order will terminate on December 22, 2041, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying settlement) in federal court alleging any violation of this Order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. Any Provision in this Order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. This Order's application to any Respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. This Order if such complaint is filed after the Order has terminated pursuant to this Provision.
